gen.metadata.title: Compact and High Gain 4 × 4 Circularly Polarized Microstrip Patch Antenna Array for Next Generation Small Satellite
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design, simulate, and fabricate a compact wideband CP microstrip antenna array for next-generation small satellite applications in the Ku-band (p. 7)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a gain of 12 dBic with minimal AR less than 1.5 dB in the angular width of ±10° (p. 9); Achieve a left-handed circularly polarized gain of more than 12 dBic with an axial ratio level below 1.5 dB in the ±10° angular space for the whole bandwidth from 8.05 GHz to 8.25 GHz (p. 1); Not mentioned; Extend the 2 × 2 array to a 4 × 4 array using a multistage SR feeding network (p. 9); Ensure the array meets the application requirements of next-generation small satellites (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the array's performance in different environmental conditions (p. 1); Not mentioned; Development of multi-band CP microstrip antenna arrays (p. 10); Investigation of the design for other frequency bands (p. 10)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Further testing and validation in real-world satellite applications (p. 10); Further testing and optimization for different satellite applications (p. 1); Optimization of the feeding network for higher efficiency (p. 10)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Limited availability of compact, high-gain, and wideband CP microstrip antenna arrays for next-generation small satellite applications (p. 7)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a high gain and compact 4 × 4 circularly polarized microstrip patch antenna array be designed for small satellites? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna array in terms of gain, bandwidth, and axial ratio? (p. 1); How can a compact wideband CP microstrip antenna array be designed for small satellite applications? (p. 7); Not mentioned; What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna array compared to existing designs? (p. 7)
esp.domain_results.axial_ratio_bandwidth: 3 dB ARBW from 8.05 GHz to 8.25 GHz (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in terms of gain, AR, and compactness (p. 9)
esp.domain_results.cross_polarization_le: Below −15 dBic in the broadside direction (p. 9)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Stable in both φ = 0° and φ = 90° planes (p. 9)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: 4 × 4 circularly polarized microstrip patch antenna array (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Sequential rotational phase feed with open stub (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: Design and validation of a dual-band circular polarization patch antenna and stripline combiner for the FSSCat mission
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design, simulate, prototype, and test a dual-frequency left-hand circular polarization patch antenna array for the 3Cat-5/A satellite (p. 8)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Design and simulate a dual-frequency circular polarization antenna stack (p. 4); Integrate and validate the Flight Model (p. 1); Perform theoretical analysis and simulations (p. 1); Design a dual-band six-patch array with a stripline combiner (p. 8); Select the best antenna type and design solution (p. 1); Simulate and prototype single-frequency circular polarization antennas (p. 4); Manufacture and test prototypes (p. 1); Characterize the combiner for the antenna array (p. 5); Perform thermal vacuum and radiofrequency characterization tests (p. 8); Define the requirements for the nadir antenna (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Explore other design solutions for even smaller and more efficient antennas (p. 1); Investigate the impact of M2.5 interface holes on combiner performance (p. 7); Conduct more extensive testing of the antenna and combiner in different environments (p. 7); Further research on improving manufacturing tolerances and dielectric constant consistency (p. 9)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Future missions should remanufacture an antenna that complies with all stated requirements (p. 9); Use the designed antenna in future CubeSat missions with similar requirements (p. 1); Further optimize the combiner design to reduce discrepancies between simulations and measurements (p. 7)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a nadir antenna for the FMPL-2 payload on the 3Cat-5/A 6U CubeSat, which must be directive, dual-band, left-hand circularly polarized, and fit within strict envelope and weight constraints (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a dual-band, high-directivity, left-hand circularly polarized antenna be designed for a CubeSat? (p. 1); What are the effects of environmental testing on the antenna's performance? (p. 8); How can the antenna be designed to fit within the specified dimensions and meet the required performance metrics? (p. 8); What are the optimal dimensions and configurations for achieving the desired performance? (p. 4); What are the optimal design solutions for meeting the envelope and performance requirements of the nadir antenna? (p. 1); How can a dual-frequency circular polarization patch antenna be designed for CubeSats? (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: S11 parameters for the dual-frequency single stack antenna: -17.5 dB at 1400 MHz, -5.7 dB at 1413 MHz, -1.5 dB at 1427 MHz, -7.3 dB at 1575.42 MHz (p. 7)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Dual-frequency left-hand circular polarization patch antenna array (p. 8)
esp.technical_specifications.frequency_b: MWR band (1413 MHz) and GPS L1 band (1575.42 MHz) (p. 4)

gen.metadata.title: A Microstrip Antenna Based on a Standing-Wave Fractal Geometry for CubeSat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a frequency reconfigurable E-shaped patch antenna using PIN diodes for operation in multiple frequency bands suitable for WMTS and MICS (p. 2214)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Reconfigure the antenna to operate in a narrow band centered at 0.5 GHz (p. 2214); Achieve dual-band operation at 0.4 and 1.4 GHz (p. 2214); Achieve triple-band operation at 0.4, 1.4, and 2 GHz (p. 2214); Achieve circular polarization and directional radiation (p. 2210); Maintain small dimensions and low weight (p. 2210)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate further miniaturization techniques (p. 2213); Investigate the performance of the antenna in real-world medical applications (p. 2214)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the proposed antenna for CubeSat applications (p. 2213); Use the proposed antenna in WMTS and MICS devices (p. 2214)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for compact, reconfigurable antennas for Wireless Medical Telemetry Systems (WMTS) and Medical Implant Communication Services (MICS) that can operate in multiple frequency bands (p. 2214)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a reconfigurable E-shaped patch antenna be designed to operate in multiple frequency bands for WMTS and MICS? (p. 2214); How can a planar antenna with circular polarization and reduced dimensions be designed for CubeSat applications? (p. 2210)
esp.domain_results.bandwidth: 335–565 MHz, 1.29–1.42 GHz, and 2.03–2.28 GHz in multiband; 300–645 MHz in single band (p. 2214)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Directional radiation with maximum radiation over the top face (H-plane) (p. 2212)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: FR4 epoxy dielectric substrate (εr = 4.4, tan δ = 0.003, h = 1.6 mm) (p. 2214)
esp.technical_specifications.frequency_b: 335–565 MHz, 1.29–1.42 GHz, and 2.03–2.28 GHz in multiband; 300–645 MHz in single band (p. 2214)

gen.metadata.title: New Concept of Telemetry X-Band Circularly Polarized Antenna Payload for CubeSat
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design, manufacture, and test a new concept of a compact circularly polarized X-band antenna for 3U CubeSats that meets the isoflux radiation pattern and other performance specifications (p. 2)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve an isoflux radiation pattern (p. 2); Not mentioned; Minimize the axial ratio in the opening angle ±65° (p. 2); Ensure the antenna is compact and thin enough to fit the 10cm x 10cm top face of a 3U CubeSat (p. 2)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the impact of different materials and manufacturing techniques (p. 5); Not mentioned; Further optimization of the antenna design to achieve exact isoflux radiation (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Consider a wider bandwidth patch to enhance performance (p. 5); Not mentioned; Use a more efficient connector to improve the antenna efficiency (p. 5)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The challenge is to integrate a high-quality circularly polarized isoflux X-band antenna on the top face of a 3U CubeSat, which is 10cm x 10cm, while meeting specific radiation and performance specifications (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: Not mentioned; How can a compact circularly polarized X-band antenna be designed to fit the top face of a 3U CubeSat? (p. 2); What design elements are necessary to achieve an isoflux radiation pattern and minimize axial ratio? (p. 2)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.cross_polarization_le: Greater than 15dB for θ varying between -60° and +60° (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Not isoflux, but meets other specifications (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: High-gain circularly polarized X-band antenna with parasitic crossed dipoles (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Sequential-phase feed microstrip circuit with a 180° hybrid ring coupler and two 90° hybrid couplers (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.superstrate: 12 parasitic crossed dipoles placed on a 45mm-diameter circle (p. 3)
Upper face: 0.8mm wide, 11.7mm long, 0.5mm gap; Back face: 0.8mm wide, 12.3mm long, gap=0 (p. 3)

gen.metadata.title: High Gain Patch Antenna for CubeSat
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a high gain patch antenna array for CubeSat to improve communication reliability and data rate in S-band (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Design a compact and high gain patch antenna array (p. 1); Ensure the antenna achieves good impedance matching in the S-band at 2.46 GHz (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the antenna array in real-world CubeSat missions (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use the high gain patch antenna array design for CubeSat applications to improve communication reliability and data rate (p. 3)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a high gain patch antenna for CubeSat to ensure reliable communication and high data rate in S-band (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a high gain patch antenna be designed for CubeSat to improve communication reliability and data rate? (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The antenna array provides a gain of 9.6 dB, which is an improvement over the patch antenna used in Tigrisat with a gain of 7.3 dB (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT 5870 (εr = 2.2, tan δ = 0.0009, h = 1.5 mm) (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: A Wideband Circularly Polarized Stacked Antenna with Corner Perturbations for CubeSats
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a single-feed circularly polarized wideband printed antenna for small satellites that can be used with NASA Near-Earth Networks (NEN) for both uplink and downlink communications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a wide axial ratio (AR) < 3dB bandwidth of 1.24 GHz from 7.02 GHz to 8.26 GHz (16.23%) (p. 1); Optimize the antenna to cover the NASA NEN’s X-band uplink and downlink frequencies (p. 1); Reduce the space required by conventional two-antenna solutions (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Conduct experimental validation of the simulation results (p. 2)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Implement the proposed antenna design in CubeSat applications to save space and power (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The challenge of designing a single, compact, circularly polarized antenna that can cover both uplink and downlink frequencies for CubeSats, reducing the space and power requirements (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a single antenna be designed to cover both uplink and downlink frequencies for CubeSats? (p. 1); What design parameters are necessary to achieve wideband circular polarization and high gain in a compact antenna? (p. 2)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Finite element method (FEM)-based simulation tool: Ansys HFSS 2020 (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Single-feed circularly polarized wideband printed antenna (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT/duroid 6010 (εr = 10.2, h = 1.27 mm) and Rogers RT/duroid 5880 (εr = 2.2, h = 1.575 mm) (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: Antenna Design for University Low Cost Student-Built CubeSat Missions
gen.objectives.main_objective: To propose a novel S-band coaxial feed patch antenna design for low-cost CubeSat missions (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve high gain and compact size (p. 1); Ensure low cost and compatibility with CubeSat dimensions (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of other design parameters and configurations (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Further testing and validation in real CubeSat missions (p. 3)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Design challenges for low-cost, high-performance S-band patch antennas for university-led CubeSat missions (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a low-cost, high-gain, compact S-band patch antenna be designed for CubeSats? (p. 1); What are the key design considerations for such antennas? (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Proposed antenna has a greater gain and is small enough to be combined with a CubeSat (p. 3)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: 3D visualization shows maximum gain of 7.114 dBi at 2.69 GHz (p. 3)

gen.metadata.title: Integration of a UHF Fractal Antenna into a 1U CubeSat for Low-Earth Orbit Mission
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and analyze a Sierpinski gasket fractal antenna for low-earth orbit CubeSat integration (p. 11)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Exhibit a reflection coefficient of -26.110 dB and a VSWR of 1.104 at the required operating frequency (p. 11); Resonate well from 800 MHz to 1 GHz with 𝒇=920 MHz (p. 11); Fabricate the antenna and perform field tests to validate its performance (p. 2); Simulate and analyze the performance of the fractal antenna using HFSS (p. 2); Achieve a peak antenna gain of 3.148 dBi (p. 11)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Perform a link budget analysis to determine power requirements and set up modulation parameters for signal transmission and reception (p. 10); Investigate optimized results for other patch geometries (p. 11)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use a ground plane with a similar geometry as the radiating patch (p. 11); Consider the CubeSat frame in antenna design (p. 11); Consider the impact of other CubeSat modules on the antenna performance in future designs (p. 9)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Very few attempts have been made to exploit the self-similarity features of fractals in the antenna design to improve the satellite communications performance (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What are the performance metrics of the proposed fractal antenna compared to conventional antennas? (p. 2); How can a Sierpinski gasket fractal antenna be integrated into a 1U CubeSat? (p. 11); How can fractal geometry be utilized to design a patch antenna for CubeSat integration? (p. 2); What are the performance benefits of using a fractal antenna over a conventional UHF antenna? (p. 11)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed fractal antenna exhibits better reflection performance and impedance matching at frequencies above 900 MHz compared to a conventional UHF antenna (p. 8)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Nearly omnidirectional in the azimuth plane (p. 9)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: FR4 substrate (𝑡 = 1.6 mm, 𝜀𝑟 = 4.3, and 𝑡𝑎𝑛𝛿 = 0.02) (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: Design of CP, High-Gain, Single-Feed, and Single-Layer S-Band Patch Antenna for Small-Satellite Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a compact, high-gain, circularly polarized microstrip patch antenna for the HORYU-IV nanosatellite S-band communication (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: To achieve an effective bandwidth of 2.73% from 2.2450 to 2.3075 GHz for 10-dB return loss and 3-dB AR bandwidth at 13 MHz (p. 6); To measure the gain and 3-dB AR beamwidth of the antenna prototype (p. 6); Maintain less than 3-dB axial ratio for the entire field of view (p. 1); Achieve a sufficient beamwidth for LEO satellite application (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the antenna's performance under different environmental conditions (p. 6); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different environmental conditions (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Further testing and integration of the antenna with other small satellites (p. 6); Integrate the antenna with the satellite body using nonconducting glue (p. 5)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Traditional satellite communication systems suffer from high costs and large antenna sizes, making them unsuitable for small satellites. Microstrip antennas, while lightweight and low-profile, often have low gain and require circular polarization for orientation-related issues (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a CP, high-gain, single-feed, and single-layer S-band patch antenna be designed for small-satellite applications? (p. 6); How can a compact, high-gain, circularly polarized microstrip patch antenna be designed for small satellite applications? (p. 2)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Environmental and mechanical testing in the KYUTECH Laboratory of Spacecraft Environment Interaction Engineering (LaSEINE) (p. 6)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The antenna achieves higher gain and broader field-of-view coverage with low axial ratio compared to similar designs (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Right-hand CP (RHCP) waves in the Z > 0 half-spaces (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Compact single-layer coaxial-probe-fed circularly polarized high-gain patch antenna (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers substrate with a relative permittivity of 2.2 (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Coaxial probe feed from the bottom (p. 3)

gen.metadata.title: Development of S band antenna for Nanosatellite
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and develop a circularly polarized, high gain, compact S band patch antenna for the HORYU-IV nanosatellite (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve the required S band impedance bandwidth, 3 dB axial ratio beamwidth, and high gain for the HORYU-IV nanosatellite (p. 2); Validate the design through simulation and measurement (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Explore further optimization techniques to enhance performance (p. 4)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the designed antenna with the HORYU-IV nanosatellite for high data-rate downlink channel (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for a high gain, circularly polarized, compact S band patch antenna for nanosatellite communications, particularly for the HORYU-IV nanosatellite (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a circularly polarized, high gain, compact S band patch antenna be designed for nanosatellite applications? (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Circularly polarized, high gain, single feed, single layer S band patch antenna (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers’s substrate with a relative permittivity of 2.2 and thickness of 1.57 mm (p. 1)

gen.metadata.title: Semi-analytical design of dual-mode resonant microstrip antennas with electrically small patch size and tilted CP angle for satellite-assisted IoV
gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a semi-analytical design approach for dual-mode resonant microstrip antennas with electrically small patch size and tilted CP angle for satellite-assisted IoV (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Determine the upper bound of patch radius for electrically small antennas (p. 3); Deduce mathematical formulas to predict the flare angle and outer/inner radius ratio for approaching an electrically small radius (p. 1); Not mentioned; Design and validate dual-mode resonant microstrip antennas with different flare angles and substrates (p. 1); Design and validate dual-mode resonant MASPAs with variable CP angles (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigation of the antenna's performance in different vehicular communication scenarios (p. 2); Not mentioned; Explore the application of the design approach to other frequency bands and substrates (p. 9)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Further experimental validation of the antenna design in real-world IoV scenarios (p. 2); Use the semi-analytical design approach to design microstrip antennas for satellite applications (p. 9)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Limited understanding of how to design microstrip antennas with electrically small patch size and frequency scannable tilted CP angle for satellite-assisted IoV (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: Not mentioned; What are the performance metrics and practical applications of such antennas? (p. 1); How can a semi-analytical design approach be developed for dual-mode resonant microstrip antennas with electrically small patch size and tilted CP angle? (p. 1); How can electrically small, dual-mode resonant, wideband CP microstrip antennas be designed for IoV applications? (p. 2); What are the key parameters and methods for achieving variable CP angles in these antennas? (p. 2)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Satimo’s Starlab near-field antenna measurement system (p. 6)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: MATLAB for eigen-root calculations, numerical simulation software (p. 3-4)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Compared to other reported tilted CP antennas, the proposed antennas exhibit a distinctive operation principle, wider tilted CP bandwidth, and larger tilted CP angle range with frequency scanning functionality (p. 9)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Tilted CP frequency scanning characteristic within the whole impedance bandwidth (p. 9)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: F4B substrate (ε_r1 = 2.65) with h_1 = 2 mm suspending on an air substrate (ε_r = 1) with h_2 = 3 mm (p. 7)

gen.metadata.title: Design of 4 × 4 Low-Proﬁle Antenna Array for CubeSat Applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To develop a low-profile microstrip antenna array with high gain for CubeSat applications, specifically for 5G frequencies (p. 11)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Miniaturize the antenna elements to fit within the CubeSat size constraints (p. 2); Design an antenna array with 16 miniaturized patch antennas (p. 11); Evaluate the performance of different array topologies to achieve high gain (p. 5); Achieve high gain performance while maintaining a low profile (p. 11); Test the performance of the array on a CubeSat structure (p. 11)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the use of aperture-coupled antennas to increase gain (p. 11); Explore the application of the design in other frequency bands (p. 11); Investigation of the impact of different substrate materials on performance (p. 9); Evaluation of the array's performance in different CubeSat configurations (p. 9)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Optimize antenna excitations for better performance (p. 11); Further optimization of the feeding network to improve performance (p. 9); Use the proposed design for 5G applications in CubeSats (p. 11)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The challenge of designing a low-profile antenna array with high gain for CubeSat applications, particularly for 5G frequencies, while keeping the overall size smaller than 10 cm × 10 cm (p. 11)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna array compared to existing designs? (p. 11); How can a high-gain microstrip antenna array be designed for CubeSat applications at low 5G frequencies? (p. 11); What is the optimal number of antenna elements for achieving high gain in a 4 × 4 topology? (p. 5); How can a microstrip antenna array be miniaturized to fit within the size constraints of a CubeSat while maintaining high gain? (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in terms of gain and size for 5G CubeSat applications (p. 10)

gen.metadata.title: Low-Cost S-Band Reconfigurable Monopole/Patch Antenna for CubeSats
gen.objectives.main_objective: To present a reconfigurable antenna concept for CubeSats that can operate in both patch and monopole states, reducing weight, cost, and power consumption (p. 5)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Design an antenna that can switch between patch and monopole modes using adhesive polyimide tapes (p. 1); Evaluate the performance of the antenna in both modes (p. 1); Design and fabricate a reconfigurable antenna (p. 5); Measure and compare the performance metrics of the antenna in both states (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the use of high-fidelity servo motors for actuation in full-framed 6U CubeSats (p. 3); Investigation of the antenna's performance in other frequency bands (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Use adhesive polyimide tapes for reconfigurable antenna designs in CubeSats (p. 1); Further studies on antenna space qualification for specific applications (p. 5)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing reconfigurable antennas for CubeSats is challenging due to mechanical constraints and limited power, but such antennas are needed for multi-functional radars and communications (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What are the performance metrics of the reconfigurable antenna in both modes? (p. 1); How can a reconfigurable antenna be designed to switch between patch and monopole modes? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics of the reconfigurable antenna in both states? (p. 5); How can a reconfigurable antenna be designed to operate in both patch and monopole states? (p. 5)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: HFSS FEM method and QNM package (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.bandwidth: 6.9% with S11 < −10 dB in patch state, 2.6% with S11 < −10 dB in monopole state (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.gain: Patch mode: 7.7 dBi, Monopole mode: 1.2 dBi (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Patch mode: Maximum radiation along θ = 0°, Monopole mode: Maximum radiation near θ = 90° (p. 3)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: Patch mode: S11 < −10 dB, Monopole mode: S11 < −10 dB (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers Arlon DiClad 880 (ϵr = 2.2, h = 3.175 mm), copper tape, polyimide tape (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Microstrip line etched on the top of the substrate and copper tape for the patch geometry (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.polarizatio: Patch mode: ˆφ polarized along the φ = 0° plane, Monopole mode: ˆθ polarized (p. 3)

gen.metadata.title: Design of a C-band High Gain Microstrip Antenna Array for CubeSat Standard
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a low-cost, high-gain C-band microstrip antenna array for CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Reduce mutual coupling between patches (p. 2); Achieve high gain and low return loss (p. 2); Ensure compatibility with CubeSat standard (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the impact of different substrate materials and configurations (p. 3)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Further testing and validation in real-world CubeSat environments (p. 3)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Common CubeSat communications in VHF and UHF bands have limited bandwidth and large dimensions, necessitating the use of microstrip antennas for higher frequencies to reduce dimensions and improve performance (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a high-gain microstrip antenna array be designed for CubeSat applications at 5.8 GHz? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: Simulations using HFSS in a free space environment (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Corporate Feed Network with Wilkinson Power Dividers, T-junction, and quarter wave transformers (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: A Multi-Band Circularly Polarized-Shared Aperture Antenna for Space Applications at S and X Bands
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and analyze a compact multiband antenna that shares the aperture of an S-band slot antenna to accommodate an X-band patch antenna for CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Replace two antennas needed in CubeSats for uplink/downlink, saving space (p. 1); Achieve high gain and maintain circular polarization over a wideband (p. 1); Not mentioned; Ensure good isolation between the S-band and X-band patches (p. 9); Achieve high gain and compact size for both S-band and X-band operations (p. 9)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Not mentioned; Investigate the performance of the antenna in different CubeSat configurations and environments (p. 1); Investigate the performance of the antenna in real CubeSat missions (p. 9)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Use the proposed antenna for CubeSat applications to reduce size and complexity (p. 9); Integrate the shared aperture antenna design in CubeSat missions to optimize space and performance (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a compact, dual-band shared aperture antenna for CubeSat applications to reduce the size and complexity of antenna systems (p. 9)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a shared aperture antenna be designed to operate in both S-band and X-band for CubeSat applications? (p. 9); How can a single antenna design accommodate both S-band and X-band operations for CubeSats? (p. 1); Not mentioned; What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna compared to existing designs? (p. 9); What are the performance metrics of a shared aperture antenna in terms of gain, bandwidth, and circular polarization? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Finite element method (FEM) based full-wave electromagnetic solver Ansys HFSS 2022 (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Achieved similar or better performances while keeping the antenna size compact compared to other recent works (p. 9)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: S-band: -30 dB (simulated), -16 dB (measured); X-band: -210 dB (simulated), -270 dB (measured) (p. 8)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Shared aperture antenna with S-band and X-band patches (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Two separate 50Ω coaxial probes for S-band and X-band patches (p. 3)

gen.metadata.title: Dual Band High Gain Shared Aperture Antenna for CubeSat Application
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design a circularly polarized shared aperture antenna (SAA) for dual band operation in S-band and X-band for CubeSats (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve high gain and compact size for the SAA (p. 1); Ensure the SAA can be placed on any of the CubeSat sides (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Validation results using another simulation tool and a fabricated prototype will be presented at the Symposium (p. 2)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: The design can be further improved by introducing an array of X-band antennas inside the perforations of the S-band antenna (p. 2)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: CubeSat developers face challenges with design complexity, space constraints, mass, and power requirements due to the need for multiple antennas for uplink and downlink communications (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a shared aperture antenna (SAA) be designed to operate in both S-band and X-band for CubeSats? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics of the proposed SAA in terms of gain, bandwidth, and axial ratio? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Finite element method-based simulation tool Ansys HFSS 2020 (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: More directive for X-band due to PRS (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT/duroid 5880 (εr = 2.2, tan δ = 0.0009, h = 0.787 mm) (p. 2)

gen.metadata.title: A Compact Microstrip Antenna with Tapered Peripheral Slits for CubeSat RF Payloads at 436 MHz: Miniaturization techniques, design & numerical results
gen.objectives.main_objective: To implement a planar, low-cost antenna solution for a CubeSat orbiter, operating around 434.8–438 MHz (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Not mentioned; Integrate the antenna with the chassis of the picosatellite (p. 1); Achieve miniaturization of the antenna while maintaining acceptable efficiency and gain performance (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate further miniaturization techniques to improve bandwidth (p. 4); Study different length distributions (tapering) for the peripheral slits to see how they affect the size-bandwidth trade-off (p. 5)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Not mentioned; Use the proposed design for CubeSat applications where miniaturization and circular polarization are required (p. 4)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a compact, low-cost, circularly polarized microstrip antenna for CubeSat picosatellites operating at 436 MHz (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What is the impact of dielectric loading and current path distortion on the performance of the antenna? (p. 1); Not mentioned; How can miniaturization techniques be applied to achieve a compact antenna design for CubeSats? (p. 1)
esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Transient Solver using Finite Integration Technique (FIT) (p. 3)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Compared to the patch antenna presented by Mathur, this design has a smaller VSWR bandwidth (2 MHz vs 7 MHz) but is more compact (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Strong back lobe, front-to-back ratio of 5 dB, beamwidth of 116° (p. 4)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_siz: 13.7 times smaller than the original size (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Microstrip patch antenna with tapered peripheral slits (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Rogers RT/Duroid ™ 6006 or Rogers RO3006™ (εr = 6.15, tan δ = 0.0019 or 0.0020, h = 6.4 mm) (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Inset-fed patch with a λg/4 transformer (p. 2)
